messages.text:
Are the `doc/build/windows.md` instructions for crosscompiling a Windows Julia from Ubuntu up to date? I quickly run into errors (with Julia master) and it soon gives up, ending with
```[...]
0063:err:module:import_dll Library libstdc++-6.dll (which is needed by L"Z:\\data\\julia-win64\\usr\\tools\\llvm-config.exe") not found
0063:err:module:import_dll Library LLVM.dll (which is needed by L"Z:\\data\\julia-win64\\usr\\tools\\llvm-config.exe") not found
0063:err:module:attach_dlls Importing dlls for L"Z:\\data\\julia-win64\\usr\\tools\\llvm-config.exe" failed, status c0000135
    PERL base/build_h.jl.phony
    PERL base/features_h.jl
    PERL base/features_h.jl
    PERL base/features_h.jl
    PERL base/file_constants.jl
    PERL base/uv_constants.jl
    PERL base/version_git.jl.phony
Makefile:109: *** unterminated call to function 'shell': missing ')'.  Stop.
make: *** [Makefile:79: julia-cli-release] Error 2```

messages.text:
Deleting
```julia-cli-release julia-cli-debug: julia-cli-% :
	@$(MAKE) $(QUIET_MAKE) -C $(BUILDROOT)/cli $*```
Allows the build to go through a bit longer

messages.text: There’s a number of unescaped comments on that line:

elements.text: There’s a number of unescaped comments on that line:

messages.text:
```diff --git a/cli/Makefile b/cli/Makefile
index 7493df64cf..306db9a5a6 100644
--- a/cli/Makefile
+++ b/cli/Makefile
@@ -106,7 +106,7 @@ ABI_UNDERSCORE := _\#\#
 else
 ABI_UNDERSCORE :=
 endif
-EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(shell echo -e "#include \"jl_exported_funcs.inc\"\n#define XX(x) $(ABI_UNDERSCORE)x\nJL_EXPORTED_FUNCS(XX)" | $(CPP) -I$(JULIAHOME)/src - | tail -n 1)
+EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(shell printf "\#include \"jl_exported_funcs.inc\"\n\#define XX(x) $(ABI_UNDERSCORE)x\nJL_EXPORTED_FUNCS(XX)" | $(CPP) -I$(JULIAHOME)/src - | tail -n 1)
 STRIP_EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(patsubst %,--strip-symbol=%,$(EXPORTED_FUNCS))
 
 # Note that if the objcopy command starts getting too long, we can use `@file` to read```

elements.text:
diff --git a/cli/Makefile b/cli/Makefile
index 7493df64cf..306db9a5a6 100644
--- a/cli/Makefile
+++ b/cli/Makefile
@@ -106,7 +106,7 @@ ABI_UNDERSCORE := _\#\#
 else
 ABI_UNDERSCORE :=
 endif
-EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(shell echo -e "#include \"jl_exported_funcs.inc\"\n#define XX(x) $(ABI_UNDERSCORE)x\nJL_EXPORTED_FUNCS(XX)" | $(CPP) -I$(JULIAHOME)/src - | tail -n 1)
+EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(shell printf "\#include \"jl_exported_funcs.inc\"\n\#define XX(x) $(ABI_UNDERSCORE)x\nJL_EXPORTED_FUNCS(XX)" | $(CPP) -I$(JULIAHOME)/src - | tail -n 1)
 STRIP_EXPORTED_FUNCS := $(patsubst %,--strip-symbol=%,$(EXPORTED_FUNCS))
 
 # Note that if the objcopy command starts getting too long, we can use `@file` to read

messages.text: It looks like what I need is <https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/shellapi/nf-shellapi-shellexecutea>  with `runas` as the verb to  spawn a separate elevated process just to access the file.  I would've expected libuv to have an option in uv_spawn to help in  this?

attachments.title: ShellExecuteA function (shellapi.h) - Win32 apps
attachments.text: Performs an operation on a specified file.

elements.text: It looks like what I need is
with
runas
as the verb to  spawn a separate elevated process just to access the file.  I would've expected libuv to have an option in uv_spawn to help in  this?

messages.text: The verbs are actually aliases that are in the windows registry, they then eventually call CreateProcess

elements.text: The verbs are actually aliases that are in the windows registry, they then eventually call CreateProcess

messages.text: You can intercept this impersonation by making your own dialog (<https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/secbp/asking-the-user-for-credentials>)

attachments.title: Asking the User for Credentials - Win32 apps
attachments.text: Your application may need to prompt the user for user name and password information to avoid storing an administrator password or to verify that the token holds the appropriate privileges.
attachments.fallback: Asking the User for Credentials - Win32 apps

elements.text: You can intercept this impersonation by making your own dialog (

messages.text: or skip it and just ask Windows to re-enable your privileges (<https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/secbp/changing-privileges-in-a-token>)

attachments.title: Changing Privileges in a Token - Win32 apps
attachments.text: Explains how to change privileges in a token by using the AdjustTokenPrivileges and CreateRestrictedToken functions.
attachments.fallback: Changing Privileges in a Token - Win32 apps

elements.text: or skip it and just ask Windows to re-enable your privileges (

messages.text: <https://blogs.windows.com/windowsdeveloper/2021/01/21/making-win32-apis-more-accessible-to-more-languages/> is pretty cool, would make for a nice project for someone to write a Julia package that automatically just exposes the entire WIN32 API :slightly_smiling_face:

attachments.title: Making Win32 APIs More Accessible to More Languages
attachments.text: Introduction Win32 APIs provide powerful functionality that let you get the most out of Windows in your applications. While these APIs are readily accessible to C and C++ developers, other languages like C# and Rust require wrappers or bindi
attachments.fallback: Windows Developer Blog: Making Win32 APIs More Accessible to More Languages

elements.text: is pretty cool, would make for a nice project for someone to write a Julia package that automatically just exposes the entire WIN32 API

messages.text: Windows Terminal has gained support for bracket paste mode <https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/395>. I don't really know whether that means anything for us, but I know <@U67D54KS8> at various points did various things that were somehow related to bracket paste, maybe? So maybe of interest?

messages.text: Yeah it doesn't seem to work

messages.text: Like bracketed paste mode is supposed to strip `julia>` when pasting in text but I can't seem to get it to do anything on the Windows side
